metadata.title:
Zeros of a growing number of derivatives of random polynomials with
  independent roots
metadata.abstract:
Let $X_1,X_2,\ldots$ be independent and identically distributed random
variables in $\mathbb{C}$ chosen from a probability measure $\mu$ and define
the random polynomial $$ P_n(z)=(z-X_1)\ldots(z-X_n)\,. $$ We show that for any
sequence $k = k(n)$ satisfying $k \leq \log n / (5 \log\log n)$, the zeros of
the $k$th derivative of $P_n$ are asymptotically distributed according to the
same measure $\mu$. This extends work of Kabluchko, which proved the $k = 1$
case, as well as Byun, Lee and Reddy who proved the fixed $k$ case.

abstract.text:
Let $X_1,X_2,\ldots$ be independent and identically distributed random
variables in $\mathbb{C}$ chosen from a probability measure $\mu$ and define
the random polynomial $$ P_n(z)=(z-X_1)\ldots(z-X_n)\,. $$ We show that for any
sequence $k = k(n)$ satisfying $k \leq \log n / (5 \log\log n)$, the zeros of
the $k$th derivative of $P_n$ are asymptotically distributed according to the
same measure $\mu$. This extends work of Kabluchko, which proved the $k = 1$
case, as well as Byun, Lee and Reddy who proved the fixed $k$ case.

body_text.text:
Let {{formula:61dfc976-7f58-49bc-bc57-8612b6edd0ec}}  be a probability measure on {{formula:361dae45-1a82-4904-a1df-f9ba8108a7cf}} X1,X2,...{{formula:08b9a76b-3263-457f-922f-9916628f3b3c}}  sampled from {{formula:58a760c0-ee2c-460e-8954-9ac57b196fc3}} , and for each {{formula:eb79d10f-0c63-49ba-9e79-5160c88bfd5b}}  define the random polynomial
{{formula:12e4f27f-0d5d-4474-b859-8dafd7d25fde}}

By the law of large numbers if we consider the empirical measure of {{formula:d84f7f30-f422-4f31-bf13-bc0d453f3ed6}} , where we a put a point mass of {{formula:10c72a4a-34d1-4284-87d4-5cba4200b902}}  at each root of {{formula:191c12e9-7891-4704-853e-070cc4bcdefa}} , then we see that the empirical measure converges to {{formula:54f9b4a5-ff6e-4309-8390-cfd0658e617a}}  as {{formula:25cde6e4-473e-4199-ad51-b8d83c7b6669}}  approaches infinity. Pemantle and Rivin {{cite:b9a0ebd270d67144ab9dc65179a9fbab756141e3}} conjectured that the same holds for the derivative {{formula:4b24a77e-3d9f-4377-ad59-4f67617075de}} . To make this precise, we define {{formula:f7391ae3-3798-4af6-8997-87974aefb592}}  to be the probability measure on {{formula:15337979-18e5-4978-a51b-fc430b3a3a3b}} Pn{{formula:31a8f78c-7527-46e2-bc02-ad376f92a967}} n(1) {{formula:7e9d1314-1e4b-4daf-87a6-80db93760b0c}} n{{formula:ed17ec5d-6749-42b8-bccd-402669dac53d}}{{formula:dd09b2da-d208-4100-b1fc-06276c748815}} 1{{formula:d307f763-9a91-45c2-8f5c-ae2c3b821c66}}{{formula:87a0ce4c-8ce2-4bb6-9b05-224f6b31a12f}}{{formula:c7ea004f-0439-4ed0-bbd2-f7a8c30a8e07}} k{{formula:d2c3c731-8163-42b4-b526-9db1209f3b11}} n(k){{formula:2f5ebdf9-f0a4-4421-8f25-8c1e2d0474f3}}
{{formula:ef4930de-96fd-439b-88da-d7b8ca04b3ef}}

Byun, Lee and Reddy {{cite:6a5c7e5f7d60603a1ba0276f3a3b12a4082481d2}} extended Kabluchko's work and showed that for each fixed {{formula:3b310f98-d662-4c16-a7ee-4b8e974328d8}} ,The work {{cite:6a5c7e5f7d60603a1ba0276f3a3b12a4082481d2}} does not state an explicit rate at which {{formula:c76239fc-456a-4866-bd12-a88738645ebb}}  can be taken to grow. An inspection of the proof shows that it depends on the Levy concentration of the non-atomic part of the random variable {{formula:1cb7dd8e-b355-40fc-991c-e76f3efa1790}}  as {{formula:b9f026e3-9fa0-47fa-8eb0-d744426084bc}}  varies in {{formula:8fd0fd85-121c-4fa5-af02-27cc04baf390}} we have {{formula:b505ebe9-f35c-4237-aa0a-c057e0379688}} .
Looking towards very high derivatives, O'Rourke and Steinerberger {{cite:411c37137ae7aaaffdf0e442e2262ade7c7b03e4}} conjecture that for each fixed {{formula:3c5499ec-f997-4108-bcff-f1a1f0295e21}} , one has that the random measure {{formula:02c503c1-94c6-4a51-b2d7-7877f99386d3}}  converges to a deterministic measure {{formula:8db1deff-0df2-46e3-b26f-d261c58ae7ef}} . In the case when the underlying measure {{formula:5b988671-2c41-40d2-8915-a844ed901f5c}}  is radial, O'Rourke and Steinerberger conjecture that the logarithmic potentials of the limiting measure {{formula:24a6689e-54a3-479e-88ea-e23725d73fa5}}  satisfy a certain partial differential equation. This partial differential equation has been studied by analysts {{cite:274b097dc706c8bbf1cd8bc91ea816b2e89c326c}}, {{cite:2c2df957e49b52b013d0ff80251b5ff347d622f3}}, and O'Rourke and Steinerberger's conjecture was proven in the special case when {{formula:4db62d8a-1875-43e2-ac30-2636e24a7150}}  has real support {{cite:6fbfb4e433acd2eb138df9b2b31277a27d3b22d2}} (see also {{cite:83ebea4722a008daec4fe32dc7e538a35ba0841d}}, {{cite:661821278f28308e68137948391703809ada0133}}). In the {{formula:ebc8e210-9677-4964-9a2f-87d0a1474cdb}}  case, the prediction of O'Rourke and Steinerberger suggests that the limiting measure should be the same as the underlying measure {{formula:998a9804-9357-41ca-87a4-2402e3af7c65}} .
We confirm this in the case that {{formula:2613d163-cdc3-4f30-bfd2-7665e7b78ca1}}  grows slightly slower than logarithmically:

Theorem 1.1 
Let {{formula:ba1e06ab-af48-45a3-9f36-67d79b33156b}}  be a probability measure on {{formula:173a60a1-420b-4fea-8480-344acac96f51}} k = k(n){{formula:2adb7415-4dbc-48d5-9a34-23682cf5e2ab}} k n5 n{{formula:e33a18e8-f2e1-45da-bb71-8dd928b123a4}} n(k){{formula:246d8cd3-2bb7-4400-b0bf-58a57fa122b9}} n{{formula:7a36ca0c-de08-42f0-bab9-62d2e10db7a7}}

Further, we show that the case of {{formula:4f2a7242-54c7-4ea9-8a30-1189378d27f9}}  would follow from an anti-concentration conjecture for elementary symmetric polynomials evaluated at i.i.d. random variables (see Conjecture REF  and Remark REF ).

Our proof of Theorem REF  takes inspiration from the potential-theoretic approach of Kabluchko's proof of the {{formula:d6a6d0c9-5aad-4cdd-b5e4-47f70f74cc34}}  case (as does the work of Byun, Lee and Reddy {{cite:6a5c7e5f7d60603a1ba0276f3a3b12a4082481d2}}); the key new step is an anti-concentration ingredient. We take a moment to sketch our proof here.

The starting point is the following classical fact from potential theory: if {{formula:320d882b-d669-4739-b001-df1aa4bf6ee2}}  is an analytic function not identically equal to zero then
{{formula:3335c729-078e-49d1-a73e-3c980259435c}}
where the Laplacian is interpreted in the distributional sense.

In particular, if we define
{{formula:692cb815-201b-4d38-bfb4-4ae08e2d5b28}}

where {{formula:bbf1b9da-a8e0-475e-8edf-86775d6edd30}}  for {{formula:adc3eda9-ea07-42ca-aaa6-6ceea0741f67}} , then we have
{{formula:856e4de0-aad0-4f60-ba1b-42a8bc39f6d1}}

By the law of large numbers, the measure {{formula:d683521a-c2d8-4ad2-9645-53068b529b35}}  tends to {{formula:d37f2f4c-0139-41ba-89d8-0cb9f143163d}}  as {{formula:e510ec90-8e03-4c57-bb20-193d12e3c6f5}} , and so in order to show {{formula:09981326-ed76-4cf4-9cb3-5b47babe5fff}}  converges to {{formula:5bfbd9fc-66eb-4e96-bbbc-0695c8f47094}}  it will be enough to show that {{formula:be0977ee-2e22-4de1-a2bb-a8fe44276b53}}  goes to 0 in a sufficiently strong sense to guarantee that {{formula:dff6ddca-e8f6-4817-b652-44b466d8fe9a}}  tends to 0.

Obtaining an upper bound on the magnitude of {{formula:1fe611d5-9586-47a7-a513-6f7842af41ed}}  involves controlling two different events: when {{formula:3192605e-9411-42ba-bf3e-264b9261906c}}  is large and when {{formula:1934e3f1-fd78-428b-b2c3-f30fe3094a86}}  very small. The former event will not be too difficult to deal with, but the latter is trickier. This comes down to an anti-concentration problem for elementary symmetric polynomials evaluated at i.i.d. random variables.

Here we think of {{formula:59aa9118-5337-4bf5-8e84-32cb155e8034}}  as above. We will deduce Lemma REF  from a theorem of Meka, Nguyen and Vu {{cite:4bf97129709125c32e5f92e4e81b970fc24c861d}} concerning anti-concentration of multi-affine polynomials of Bernoulli random variables.

After showing pointwise bounds on {{formula:1acc33ba-9a46-4cef-8a51-0367fed099b5}} , we upgrade these bounds by showing that they hold in some uniform sense. To take care of this, we again follow Kabluchko and lean on a lemma from Tao and Vu {{cite:9a86d0df24557068bc75f2d935a01c38695d5a11}} stating that tightness of an {{formula:a0a1379c-2fa8-419d-b566-82a42bc88ca3}} -norm will be sufficient to deduce convergence in probability of the measures. For this, we use the Poisson-Jensen formula to relate values of {{formula:e18a2e88-4c81-4ed9-8add-56f9b09e46da}}  in a disk to its values on the boundary of a larger disk, and show uniform bounds at the origin and on the boundary of this disk.

Throughout, we use {{formula:a220dd9f-cbd1-4807-a5c4-44b797574af1}}  to be the disk of radius {{formula:2adb5fba-0e13-4420-ab9e-d999520534f1}}  centered at {{formula:6695f782-05a6-4875-ab95-21d686eff9f7}}  and abbreviate {{formula:791b481d-535f-4905-b8f5-4bc95a5786b2}}  as {{formula:af04d11e-5404-4d1a-820e-e18c5f10fb08}} . We write {{formula:665909f5-c70d-4559-835f-2d4d8c4796a9}}  for the standard (2-real-dimensional) Lebesgue measure on {{formula:b853320b-5331-4b6d-9013-0d51afc3898f}} z=+z--z{{formula:7064d84c-503e-4066-9afb-2edf63fd5c9d}}{{formula:aac1638b-fcb8-47a8-8a86-65ab8425bcca}}{{formula:199a62f4-12a7-4e3d-986d-302b05c48722}} -0=+{{formula:0371d03a-11d5-4627-9d47-3ed97a56dbca}}
We will show two main Lemmas. First we show pointwise convergence of {{formula:e80f9658-056d-4034-a54d-78a7c255ea14}}  almost everywhere:

Lemma 2.1 
There is a set {{formula:0bdb0f6f-cd59-4d79-a99f-427d7543c2a3}} m(F) = 0{{formula:7cf31353-ffca-46dd-853c-d88bdf8d62be}} zF{{formula:ebc11ec3-cda0-49db-bfba-44c6efc83894}} k n5 n{{formula:d0f92406-b431-4704-880a-59431cb68df3}}

In order to prove Theorem REF , we will need to upgrade Lemma REF 
from pointwise convergence to a more uniform mode of convergence. By a lemma of Tao and Vu {{cite:9a86d0df24557068bc75f2d935a01c38695d5a11}}, it will be sufficient to show tightness of a second moment.
is tight.
We now deduce Theorem REF  from Lemmas REF  and REF .
We will show two main Lemmas. First we show pointwise convergence of {{formula:e80f9658-056d-4034-a54d-78a7c255ea14}}  almost everywhere:

Lemma 2.1 
There is a set {{formula:0bdb0f6f-cd59-4d79-a99f-427d7543c2a3}} m(F) = 0{{formula:7cf31353-ffca-46dd-853c-d88bdf8d62be}} zF{{formula:ebc11ec3-cda0-49db-bfba-44c6efc83894}} k n5 n{{formula:d0f92406-b431-4704-880a-59431cb68df3}}

In order to prove Theorem REF , we will need to upgrade Lemma REF 
from pointwise convergence to a more uniform mode of convergence. By a lemma of Tao and Vu {{cite:9a86d0df24557068bc75f2d935a01c38695d5a11}}, it will be sufficient to show tightness of a second moment.
is tight.
We now deduce Theorem REF  from Lemmas REF  and REF .

We will deduce Lemma REF  from a Theorem of Meka, Nguyen and Vu concerning anti-concentration of multi-affine polynomials of Bernoulli random variables. To properly state their theorem, we will need a bit of setup.

We will consider multi-affine polynomials of the form
{{formula:bcb698c8-0c43-4f20-8c5c-56e25b45e0c2}}

where the coefficients {{formula:4ab06e70-3092-471c-8c13-d9c702047697}}  are real and the degree of {{formula:8dbb6310-3191-42c4-a231-190b1a566880}}  is the largest {{formula:f16854f1-ffea-4f95-8694-83bb64e58984}}  so that {{formula:2ea198f5-3b0e-49ba-94a1-22bcffde33e7}} . If {{formula:72865ba9-4be8-48ea-93c3-c198f4aaf784}}  is of degree {{formula:621ffa89-898c-4d63-9fd5-db3e6227a6d2}} , then the rank of {{formula:e1ee411c-fa61-4118-8e30-b214c5d6fe16}}  is the largest integer {{formula:54be2c63-ce95-43c9-989d-53feefa354ae}}  such that there exist disjoint sets {{formula:c809d4aa-b2cc-4a0b-b296-0b8bdbb33d69}}  of size {{formula:654a61e0-be46-4a9b-b6b3-0631ddba96a0}}  with {{formula:edfc2943-31de-4dde-bcc1-9f96fa562950}}  for all {{formula:cb5cdbfa-157c-45a0-90be-bbfe8155cbdc}} .

Theorem 3.1 (Theorem 1.7 of {{cite:4bf97129709125c32e5f92e4e81b970fc24c861d}}) 
There is an absolute constant {{formula:4a8d60d3-7011-4240-8cd5-fd834f9b8211}}  such that the following holds.
Let {{formula:30ad60c7-b251-426f-8354-c0ce5b01390c}}  be a polynomial of the form (REF ) whose rank {{formula:25a1d0c5-6b01-4c0b-800c-18e31c9700cb}} . Let {{formula:0efbed6f-f359-4779-9d25-99f1baf4a5cd}}  be such that {{formula:adb20ac2-5f5c-4e31-8908-089979e2bffb}}  where {{formula:5e77a72c-1282-418f-8d5c-ac7696e6eed2}} . Then for any interval {{formula:66b6f2aa-bb37-43f4-84bd-e87269e36a47}}  of length 1, if we let {{formula:41cd81ee-b2be-4b4c-82d9-6f2e7040ccc9}}  be i.i.d. Bernoulli{{formula:6be0a311-294e-4199-9f3e-0deb586d8365}}  random variables we have
{{formula:e499fbea-042b-405a-a8e3-221288fca36c}}

To apply this Theorem to the case of Lemma REF —where the variables are complex valued and arbitrary—we will use the non-degeneracy to first sample most of the randomness of each {{formula:ec63001f-1996-4d8e-9bf2-c13368173bdd}} , leaving a Bernoulli random variable's worth of randomness behind; then we will take either the real or imaginary part of the subsequent polynomial and show that it has sufficiently high rank with high probability.
We believe that Lemma REF  is suboptimal, and that in fact the same statement should hold provided {{formula:76848110-0ef5-4406-9a90-5a3532b205cc}} .

The sharpest general statements for anti-concentration for multi-affine polynomials are provided by the work of Meka, Nguyen and Vu {{cite:4bf97129709125c32e5f92e4e81b970fc24c861d}}, for which Conjecture REF  lies well beyond the currently known bounds. For an example of a polynomial of very high degree for which anti-concentration is known, see Tao and Vu's work on the permanent of a random matrix {{cite:372ce6d089ccfefa6a3497286c5ae29d6c0dc935}} (see also {{cite:e9dd97f87f1e9d714224a74df1f89d38fd961194}}).

Remark 4.2 
We note that substituting a positive resolution to Conjecture REF  for Lemma REF  would immediately upgrade Theorem REF  to hold for all {{formula:665e0daf-e261-41b8-abf7-a00a925d93a8}} ; indeed, throughout the proof the only assumptions on {{formula:c77f0d0d-4637-4699-80f0-4b7e4dce3b50}}  used are that {{formula:f284858c-f669-4318-8ea3-dddc6f580aa6}}  and that the conclusion of Lemma REF  holds. Additionally, due to Lemma REF , one can further assume that the variable {{formula:ac1d6a03-8e18-47a3-996a-3467de7e36fb}}  in Conjecture REF  satisfies {{formula:54b7c9a7-e42f-402a-b05e-529be047db96}} .
We also highlight a conjecture of KabluchkoThis conjecture was stated at the Workshop on Random Functions in April, 2021.:

Conjecture 4.3 (Kabluchko)  
For any probability measure {{formula:63cd9971-0e35-4349-be31-2b46a04811c7}}  on {{formula:5789166d-3c2b-48d1-8672-4d3cd2d6fb0a}} n(1){{formula:4726510d-6ef2-4292-b4c2-f2f49eccd191}}{{formula:696224b0-c3c0-4b4d-8fa4-a06baa716466}} n {{formula:9d0c5e10-5c45-47a6-949d-5930dc13c4ff}}
We suspect that Theorem REF  can also be upgraded to almost sure convergence. The main difficulty appears to be in upgrading Lemma REF  to almost-sure convergence.

7af1a0ac-8997-4925-b8c1-802fcbbb85f4.latex: F=\lbrace z\in  \int _{|y-z|^{-1}d\mu (y)=\infty \rbrace . Then m(F) = 0.}{\begin{xmlelement*}{proof}Since \mu  is a probability measure we have that \int \limits _{y:|y-z|\ge 1}|z-y|^{-1}d\mu (y)\le 1 for all z. Thus F is equal to the set of z for which \int _{B_1(z)} |y - z|^{-1}\,d\mu (y) = \infty . Apply Fubini^{\prime }s theorem to compute{\begin{@align*}{1}{-1}\int \limits _{\int \limits _{B_1(z)}|z-y|^{-1}d\mu (y)dm(z)= \int \limits _{ \int \limits _{B_1(y)} |z-y|^{-1}dm(z)d\mu (y)=2\pi .}}Thus m(F)=0.\end{@align*}}\end{xmlelement*}}{\begin{xmlelement*}{proof}If the random variable X_1 is almost surely a constant, then the Lemma follows easily, and so we assume that X_1 is non-degenerate.\end{xmlelement*}First, we show that for every fixed z\in F and every {\varepsilon }>0, we have\begin{equation}\lim _{n\rightarrow \infty } \mathbf {P}\left[\frac{1}{n} \log |L_n^{(k)}(z)|\ge {\varepsilon }\right]=0.\end{equation}Indeed, defining Y_i = (z - X_i)^{-1} for all i \in [n], Markov^{\prime }s inequality bounds{\begin{@align}{1}{-1}\mathbf {P}\left[ |L_n^{(k)}(z)|\ge e^{{\varepsilon }n}\right]\le e^{-{\varepsilon }n} {\mathbf {E}}[|L_n^{(k)}(z)|] \le e^{-{\varepsilon }n} \binom{n}{k} \left({\mathbf {E}}|Y_1|\right)^k\,.\end{@align}}Since z \in F, the expectation {\mathbf {E}}|Y_1| is finite. Thus, the right-hand-side tends to zero as long as k = o(n) and so the limit (\ref {eq:Ln_upper_bound}) follows.}

62383c56-6b84-4178-aa31-023f8c66f1dc.latex: \int _{B_R} \int _{ |z - y|^{-1} d\mu (y) \,dm(z) < \infty \,.By switching the outer integral into polar coordinates, we see that for Lebesgue-almost-all R > 0 we have that \begin{equation}\int _{0}^{2\pi } \int _{ \frac{1}{|R e^{i\theta } - y|}\,d\mu (y)\,d\theta < \infty \,.}Throughout, we assume that R satisfies this assumption.\end{equation}We now write the Poisson-Jensen formula for \log |L_n^{(k)}(z)|: Let R>r be chosen as above, let x_{1,n},\ldots , x_{j_n,n} denote the zeros of P_n(z) in the disk B_R, and let y_{1,n},\ldots , y_{\ell _n, n} be the zeros of P_n^{(k)}(z) in the disk B_R. Also note that j_n\le n and \ell _n\le n. We take the following standard facts about the Poisson-Jensen formula from \cite [Chapter 8]{markushevich}:}\begin{lemma}[Poisson-Jensen formula]\begin{equation}\log |L_n^{(k)}(z)|=I_n^{(k)}(z;R)+\sum _{\ell =1}^{\ell _n} \log \left|\frac{R(z-y_{\ell ,n})}{R^2-\bar{y}_{\ell ,n}z}\right|-\sum _{j=1}^{j_n} \log \left|\frac{R(z-x_{j,n})}{R^2-\bar{x}_{j,n}z}\right|,\end{equation}where\begin{equation}I_n^{(k)}(z;R)=\frac{1}{2\pi } \int _{0}^{2\pi } \log |L_n^{(k)}(R e^{i\theta })|P_R(|z|, \theta -\arg z)d\theta \end{equation}where P_R denotes the Poisson kernel\begin{equation}P_R(r, \phi )=\frac{R^2-r^2}{R^2+r^2-2Rr \cos \phi },\;\;\;r\in [0,R],\, \phi \in [0,2\pi ].\end{equation}\end{lemma}
